ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a better understanding of queer theory with specific cultural characteristics and the various difficulties that come with queer organizing across various other divisions whether personal, cultural, national, political, or otherwise.

I learned a lot about different global conceptions of gender and sexuality which was super interesting to me, having been raised in a very Western perspective on sexuality. We also learned a lot about different approaches to human rights worldwide which was cool.

I learned about gender and sexuality in various global contexts, as well as how those individual contexts influence one another in the interconnected transnational sphere. I greatly enhanced my human rights vocabulary and knowledge of the layers within LGBTQ+ advocacy in both Western and non-Western landscapes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was definitely very well thought out and the readings and subject areas showed an attention to detail and awareness of the material that made the class feel very impactful and focused. I think the course lacked enough structure to help clarify class discussions, but the professor attempted to remedy this fact more later on by giving discussion questions. I think it might be better to limit the readings to allow for more specificity in the kinds of class conversations that take place, and allowing students to guide the discussion more might also help. However, I recognize that this dimension of the course depends a lot on the atmosphere of the room and the nature of those willing to discuss.

I think overall, it was a really cool class. Discussions were good and we also each did a short presentation on something related to the class which I thought was interesting. Readings were a little up and down. Most of the readings we did were really interesting but there were some that were quite dense and a few that overlapped a lot. I feel like some weeks could've been balanced more with maybe one legal/dense reading and one article that was easier to read.
I loved taking this course. All of the readings were carefully selected and paired in a way that was conducive to insightful and courageous in-class dialogue. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to other students especially if they want to engage with subject areas with intersections in political science, economics, anthropology, race studies, and history. I think overall, the course does an incredible amount to expand one's view of queer organizing and its history in several cultural and geographic contexts.

I would! It was more narrow in focus than some of my other WGSS classes, which I think is good to know for someone considering the class. It was very interesting though. Professor Reid would sometimes get very excited about a topic and it would be slightly less discussion but that's okay.

I highly recommend taking this course! It was by far one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. The professor has an extensive background in LGBTQ+ advocacy and shares valuable insights during class. If you're passionate and/or interested in gender, sexuality, and their global dimensions, take this course!
